title: Period of SHM - claim about period

content.question: A cart of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is attached to a horizontal spring with spring constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> and undergoes simple harmonic motion on a horizontal surface with period <math alttext="T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>T</mi></math>. A student claims that quadrupling both the mass and the spring constant will cause the cart to undergo simple harmonic motion with a period of <math alttext="2 T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>T</mi></math>. Is the claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the period is proportional to the square root of the mass.
Yes, because the period is proportional to the square root of the ratio <math alttext="the fraction m over k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>m</mi><mi>k</mi></mfrac></math>.
No, because quadrupling the mass and the spring constant will cause the period to quadruple.
No, because the ratio <math alttext="the fraction m over k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>m</mi><mi>k</mi></mfrac></math> will not change if both quantities are quadrupled.

content.answer: No, because the ratio <math alttext="the fraction m over k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>m</mi><mi>k</mi></mfrac></math> will not change if both quantities are quadrupled.
